cards.back: The ratio V/I in the phasor domain: V = ZI. It's the AC generalisation of resistance, measured in Ohms (Ω). It's generally complex.

cards.front: What is the impedance of a resistor?
cards.back: Z_R = R (purely real). Voltage and current are in phase — no phase shift.

cards.front: What is the impedance of an inductor?
cards.back: Z_L = jωL = ωL∠90°. Voltage leads current by 90°. At DC (ω=0), ZL=0 (short). At high ω, ZL→∞ (open).

cards.front: What is the impedance of a capacitor?
cards.back: Z_C = 1/(jωC) = (1/ωC)∠(-90°). Voltage lags current by 90°. At DC (ω=0), ZC→∞ (open). At high ω, ZC→0 (short).

cards.front: State the ELI the ICE man mnemonic.
cards.back: ELI: in an inductor (L), voltage (E) leads current (I). ICE: in a capacitor (C), current (I) leads voltage (E).

cards.front: What are resistance and reactance in Z = R + jX?
cards.back: R is resistance (always ≥ 0 for passive elements, dissipates energy). X is reactance (positive = inductive, negative = capacitive, stores energy).
Y = 1/Z = I/V, measured in Siemens (S). Written as Y = G + jB where G is conductance and B is susceptance.

cards.front: Why is the impedance of an inductor zero at DC?
cards.back: Z_L = jωL. At DC, ω = 0, so Z_L = 0 (short circuit). The inductor only opposes CHANGING current. With DC (constant current), there's no opposition.

cards.front: Why is imaginary impedance associated with energy storage rather than dissipation?
cards.back: When V and I are 90° apart, average power P = ½VmIm·cos(90°) = 0. The element absorbs energy during one quarter-cycle and returns it during the next — no net dissipation.

cards.front: For a complex Z = R + jX, what is the admittance Y = G + jB?
cards.back: Y = 1/(R+jX) = (R-jX)/(R²+X²). So G = R/(R²+X²) and B = -X/(R²+X²). G ≠ 1/R in general!
